definition:
Let $R$ be a commutative ring with unity. A [*free module*]{} over $R$
is a (unital) module isomorphic to a direct sum of copies of $R$. In
particular, as every abelian group is a $\mathbb{Z}$-module, a [*free
abelian group*]{} is a direct sum of copies of $\Bbb{Z}$. This is
equivalent to saying that the module has a [*free basis*]{}, i.e. a set
of elements with the that every element of the module can be uniquely
expressed as an linear combination over $R$ of elements of the free
basis. In the case that a free module over $R$ is a sum of finitely many
copies of $R$, then the number of copies is called the [*rank*]{} of the
free module.

An alternative definition of a free module is via its universal
property: Given a set $X$, the free $R$-module $F(X)$ on the set $X$ is
equipped with a function $i:X\rightarrow F(X)$ satisfying the property
that for any other $R$-module $A$ and any function $f:X\rightarrow A$,
there exists a unique $R$-module map $h:F(X)\rightarrow A$ such that
$(h\circ i)=f$.
